The Filipino Language

Photo by Pyrrhus Cunanan on Unsplash

Filipino is the national language of the Philippines. It is one of the country's two official languages, the other being English. Its status as a language is further cemented by its inclusion in the country's 1987 constitution. Here, it is stated that "the Government shall take steps to initiate and sustain the use of Filipino as a medium of official communication and as language of instruction in the educational system."

According to the Philippine Statistics Authority, the Philippines has a total population of around 109 billion people, and it is estimated that a majority of the population speaks Filipino. On any of the country's beautiful islands, you're sure to find someone who speaks Filipino.

Filipino is taught in schools from the primary level up to the secondary level. It is also taught in tertiary institutions as a subject. For those who live outside the Philippines, it might be hard to find resources to learn the language. If you primarily speak in English and you want to learn Filipino, this website is a great way to start!

Photo by Eugene Alvin Villar on Wikimedia

Parts of Speech

Filipino has 10 parts of speech and are analogous to the 9 parts of speech in English. Unlike English which can describe a noun using an adjective such as "beautiful lady" without modifiers, Filipino uses a ligature to connect the adjective to the noun, such as the "-ng" in "magandang babae".

  • Nouns - Pangngalan
  • Pronouns - Panghalip
  • Verbs - Pandiwa
  • Adjectives - Pang-uri
  • Adverbs - Pang-abay
  • Prepositions - Pang-ukol
  • Conjunctions - Pangatnig
  • Articles - Pantukoy
  • Interjections - Padamdam
  • Ligatures - Pang-angkop

Itching to start? Let's go and start with nouns!
